lexUnit.name: thirst.n
lexUnit.definition: COD: a feeling of needing or wanting to drink.

sentence.text: They were a year in the planning and a year in the building , and carry all generators , control systems , prizes and a generous helping of Guinness to slake visitors ' thirsts after their visit .
I made this round trip between church and house three times and settled in the end for slaking my thirst from a tap in the churchyard .
Thirst , for instance , is not a cultural issue , but the means selected by the individual to slake his thirst -- tea , coffee , fruit juices , etc -- is influenced by his cultural background .
So the people 's thirst is slaked .
The water pipes satisfied their thirst and washed away their whiffies .
The children are dying of thirst . "
In another study George Bokert increased the degree of thirst in his subjects by not only depriving them of water for twenty-four hours , but also giving them a salty meal before going to bed .
Both these experiments and the studies on the effects of hunger and thirst on dreaming demonstrate the unpredictability of dreaming , explicable only in terms of semantics .
His story was that he had collapsed with exhaustion and thirst when a passing American schooner had seen his distress signals and taken him aboard .
` We could hardly have our new tutor dying of thirst , " he added .
There is also a magnificent palm tree for shade where you can quench your thirst with a cool drink from the hotel bar which opens onto the sun terrace .
When they had quenched their thirst a little , they returned to the bushes to pick more berries , staying a little closer to each other .
Maggie had developed a raging thirst and wondered if she could get a drink at the Commemorative Hall .
Bananas and apples helped to stave off the effect of raging thirst â€¦
